instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD_R: What is CPUVR_PGOOD_R? CPUVR_PGOOD_R is a signal that comes from CPU_VR_EN that is necessary along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD.
definitions.SPI_MLB_MOSI: What is SPI_MLB_MOSI? SPI_MLB_MOSI is a line between the SPI ROM BIOS chip and resistors that sit between it and the PCH. This often corrodes on Macbook Airs due to liquid damage and results in missing PM_SLP_S4_L and no bootup..
definitions.SYS_PWORK_R: What is SYS_PWORK_R? This is a typo of SYS_PWROK When you see SYS_PWORK_R, assume they meant to type SYS_PWROK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> jumping sleep signals
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

pp3v42 present
green light
damage to <RESISTOR>R6120</RESISTOR>/6121 
ran wire and replaced.


ppbus 8.58v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.58
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.58
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5.01v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.28v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 3.4v



<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> jumping high then low.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> jumping high then low.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> jumping
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> jumping
the above 4 jump 3 times (so its trying to turn on) then goto 0v.

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0v


<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> 

enables
pin12 3.4v
pin21 3.4v
pin4 0v
pin 20 - <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0v

Tried replacing <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, no change. No further evidence of liquid damage.

PCH dead ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> jumping sleep signals
threads.message: So it is power cycling. The usual suspects apply, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, J6100, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and termination resistors/traces. Is CPU Vcore pulsing too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> jumping sleep signals
threads.message:
Thank you Duke. Yes Vcore is also pulsing. J6100 was removed already. Board was clean apart from the damage trace and <RESISTOR>R6120</RESISTOR> / <RESISTOR>R6121</RESISTOR>. I replaced area and ran a jumper wire. I've checked for continuity between all the termination resistors to the right of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and the relevant pins. <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses also along with <SIGNAL>SYS_PWORK_R</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL> .
On <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> i get steadt 3.32v on pins 1,2,3 6,7,8 the only voltage jumping there is pin 5 <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_MOSI</SIGNAL> which goes from 2.2 to 3.3v regularly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> jumping sleep signals
threads.message: Must be a corroded trace or via to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> or termination resistors. Check all traces, remove <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and resistors if necessary and then check diode mode to verify continuity to CPU and SMC.
